nodes.text: The Operations Corridor narrows into a pocket of signage and hardware: (pause) a red-painted lock point. (pause) A laminated placard stack on a clip. (pause) A label maker bolted down, like it’s part of the facility. (pause) A single inspection tag hangs on a wire ring. (pause) The rest is empty hooks and old adhesive shadows.
A placard over the hasp reads: “LOCKOUT/TAGOUT — ALL ENERGY SOURCES.” Someone underlined “ALL” twice, carefully.

choices.text: use “Print TEMP tags and apply LOTO.”
leave “Step away from the lock point.”

nodes.text: The top placard is current enough to be embarrassing. (pause) It wants: date; work order; name; contact; device ID; and “reason for isolation.” (pause) There’s a handwritten note in the margin: “TEMP TAGS OK IF PHOTO ATTACHED.” (pause) The handwriting is precise—like someone trying not to be remembered.

The subpoints list runs longer than the hardware suggests: ventilation interlock and panel feed; auxiliary drive. (pause) And a “legacy bypass” with no corresponding label. (pause) A sticker says: “DO NOT REMOVE — HISTORICAL.” (pause) It is peeling from the bottom up—stubbornly.
The wall phone answers on the second ring, like it was already held.
“Before you say anything, this line is recorded for ‘process continuity.’ Which is not surveillance. Contractually.”
“Need LOTO coverage. I’ve got one real tag.”

“Right, so: the question is not ‘one tag.’ The question is: are you creating a traceable isolation condition that is comparable to full application. Comparable doesn’t mean identical. It means defensible, after the fact, in a room where nobody remembers you.”

choices.text: ask “Does a printed TEMP tag count?”
ask “What do I write so it passes?”
persuade “Give me wording that won’t come back on me.”

nodes.text: “It counts as a marker. The lock counts as the lock. The tag counts as the communication of the lock. A temporary tag is— and I hate this phrase— a communication of a communication. Which is allowed, if documented as such, and if no one pretends it is anything else.”

“Write what you did. Not what you meant. Not what you were trying to do. Date/time. Device IDs. ‘Primary lock applied at main point.’ ‘TEMP tags affixed at subpoints due to inventory limitation.’ And note that the limitation is administrative, not improvisational. Improvisational implies agency.”

“You sign your action. I witness your statement. I’m not authorizing. I’m not preventing. I’m creating a record that you said you complied. There’s a difference, and it is the only reason my job exists.”

“Use this: ‘Isolation established at primary lock point; subpoint TEMP tags applied as markers due to documented inventory limitation; photographs attached; device IDs cross-referenced to placard list.’ Boring. Specific. No adjectives. Adjectives are where blame hides.”
“I can’t write your sentence for you. I can only tell you what auditors will ask: who, what, when, where, and the exact reason you deviated from ideal supply conditions.”
The dial tone returns like a relieved sigh.
You hold credential to the camera above the placard stack. Text smears; seal is annoyingly clear.
“Okay. That helps. Not because it changes physics. Because it changes who gets asked why the physics happened.”

choices.text: use “Proceed with TEMP tags and main tag.”

nodes.text: “I will note: ‘Action taken under OLEA closure authority, pending record reconciliation.’ That is not acceptance. That is a sentence that prevents follow-up calls.”

The label maker wakes up with a thin, offended beep. (pause) The tape cartridge is half-full and slightly yellowed. (pause) It looks like it’s been waiting longer than it should. (pause) You type device IDs from the placard list, one at a time. (pause) Then you print TEMP tags with matching dates.

Apply the single real inspection tag at the main lock point. (pause) Then affix printed TEMP tags at listed subpoints. (pause) Align them so they look intentional. (pause) Annotate the placard: date/time; work order; device IDs. (pause) Add the reason: “Inventory limitation — TEMP tags used at subpoints; primary isolation tagged at main.”
“Just to be explicit: you are declaring the isolation condition established. I am recording your declaration. That is the cleanest wording we have.”
“LOTO set.”
“LOTO documented. Which is the version of reality that survives.”
You leave the lock point as you found it: one real tag on a ring. (pause) And a placard that expects a world with supplies. (pause) The corridor stays open to the adjacent screens.
